title: How to Manage Yourself

steps.headline: Understand what your personal goals for this job are.
steps.description: Write down one to three goals, and make sure they are something you believe in. Managing a workload usually requires motivation, and these goals should keep you motivated. If you can’t find personal reasons that you are doing this job, then brainstorm to find them or reevaluate whether you will be able to complete the job.

steps.headline: Create a personal reward, should the job be a success.
steps.description: Creating quarterly or yearly goals can help you stay motivated to hit deadlines or goals.

steps.headline: Get specialty help for things you can’t manage yourself.
steps.description: This could be in the form of a graphic designer, bookkeeper, administrative assistant or IT specialist. Don’t spend too much time trying to accomplish everything, when it may result in failure to complete the job you set out to do.

steps.headline: Learn to say “no.” Turning down work that you can’t do or don’t have the time to do is hard for most entrepreneurs.
steps.description: Saying “yes” to everything will overload you and force you off track. Only take additional jobs when you can guarantee completion.

steps.headline: Schedule regular vacations.
steps.description: If possible, leave someone you trust in charge, or simply choose a time when you are able to clear your head and invest some time in your personal interests. If possible, leave your home base for a week or so, so you aren’t drawn back into work.

steps.headline: Watch your attitude closely.
steps.description: Try to remain positive through stressful periods. If you find yourself starting to become negative toward your work, it’s time to adjust your expectations.

steps.headline: Write a to-do list.
steps.description: Although this may not be your style, it will help to get things out of your head and onto paper. You will be able to focus better if you know that you will not forget what you have to do today.

steps.headline: Write your to-do list in order of priority.
steps.description: Get to know your deadlines and complete the projects in order of deadlines. If you don’t do this, you will set yourself up for a stressful day at work—always in crisis trying to meet looming deadlines.

steps.headline: Don’t overbook.
steps.description: If your to-do list is not something you can reasonably accomplish in a day, create a to-do list for the following day, so that you can reduce the load. When faced with too much work, you may become unmotivated knowing you can’t accomplish everything. Opt to have a five or seven day to-do list. Use a dry erase board or pencil, so that you can change it every morning before you begin. It will result in fewer things falling through the cracks.

steps.headline: Try compartmentalizing your time.
steps.description: If you haven’t tried it before, schedule your day where you have two periods for answering emails, a period for calling and time for Internet use and several breaks. Calls, emails and texts can break up the flow of work on a project, resulting in distractions and procrastination.

steps.headline: Set a timer.
steps.description: Your cell phone probably has an easy timer. Unless you like to work at something for more than a few hours, set an alarm at hour intervals to get up, move around and change tasks.

steps.headline: Establish an end to the workday.
steps.description: Avoid checking your work email after this time. Most successful entrepreneurs are able to establish a work/life balance that includes relationships, hobbies and vacations.

steps.headline: Clean your desk and file papers before you leave the office each day.
steps.description: Return to a clean, uncluttered slate in the morning.

steps.headline: Schedule times to report or examine your own work.
steps.description: If you are a freelancer, you may not be required to be accountable to anyone. However, thoughtful examination of your work every quarter can help you hone your skills.

steps.headline: Seek educational opportunities when you can.
steps.description: If you are lacking essential skills or knowledge about an issue, take it upon yourself to read a relevant book, enroll in a class or watch a webinar.

steps.headline: Get a mentor.
steps.description: If you know someone in the field that you respect highly, ask the person to go to coffee or lunch, or even a Skype session, to learn how they have managed their professional life.

steps.headline: Trust others to complete tasks.
steps.description: Micromanaging others is not an effective way to manage yourself. Delegating when you need to may determine how successful you are.

steps.headline: Build relationships while doing business.
steps.description: It is easier to keep jobs than to find new ones. Managing yourself may involve devoting a portion of your time to speaking with clients or following up with previously completed jobs.

text: Managing Your Position Understand what your personal goals for this job are. Write down one to three goals, and make sure they are something you believe in. Managing a workload usually requires motivation, and these goals should keep you motivated. If you can’t find personal reasons that you are doing this job, then brainstorm to find them or reevaluate whether you will be able to complete the job. Create a personal reward, should the job be a success. Creating quarterly or yearly goals can help you stay motivated to hit deadlines or goals. Get specialty help for things you can’t manage yourself. This could be in the form of a graphic designer, bookkeeper, administrative assistant or IT specialist. Don’t spend too much time trying to accomplish everything, when it may result in failure to complete the job you set out to do. Learn to say “no.” Turning down work that you can’t do or don’t have the time to do is hard for most entrepreneurs. Saying “yes” to everything will overload you and force you off track. Only take additional jobs when you can guarantee completion. Schedule regular vacations. If possible, leave someone you trust in charge, or simply choose a time when you are able to clear your head and invest some time in your personal interests. If possible, leave your home base for a week or so, so you aren’t drawn back into work. Watch your attitude closely. Try to remain positive through stressful periods. If you find yourself starting to become negative toward your work, it’s time to adjust your expectations. Managing Your Work Day Write a to-do list. Although this may not be your style, it will help to get things out of your head and onto paper. You will be able to focus better if you know that you will not forget what you have to do today. Write your to-do list in order of priority. Get to know your deadlines and complete the projects in order of deadlines. If you don’t do this, you will set yourself up for a stressful day at work—always in crisis trying to meet looming deadlines. Don’t overbook. If your to-do list is not something you can reasonably accomplish in a day, create a to-do list for the following day, so that you can reduce the load. When faced with too much work, you may become unmotivated knowing you can’t accomplish everything. Opt to have a five or seven day to-do list. Use a dry erase board or pencil, so that you can change it every morning before you begin. It will result in fewer things falling through the cracks. Try compartmentalizing your time. If you haven’t tried it before, schedule your day where you have two periods for answering emails, a period for calling and time for Internet use and several breaks. Calls, emails and texts can break up the flow of work on a project, resulting in distractions and procrastination. Set a timer. Your cell phone probably has an easy timer. Unless you like to work at something for more than a few hours, set an alarm at hour intervals to get up, move around and change tasks. Establish an end to the workday. Avoid checking your work email after this time. Most successful entrepreneurs are able to establish a work/life balance that includes relationships, hobbies and vacations. Clean your desk and file papers before you leave the office each day. Return to a clean, uncluttered slate in the morning. Adjusting Work Procedures Schedule times to report or examine your own work. If you are a freelancer, you may not be required to be accountable to anyone. However, thoughtful examination of your work every quarter can help you hone your skills. Seek educational opportunities when you can. If you are lacking essential skills or knowledge about an issue, take it upon yourself to read a relevant book, enroll in a class or watch a webinar. Get a mentor. If you know someone in the field that you respect highly, ask the person to go to coffee or lunch, or even a Skype session, to learn how they have managed their professional life. Trust others to complete tasks. Micromanaging others is not an effective way to manage yourself. Delegating when you need to may determine how successful you are. Build relationships while doing business. It is easier to keep jobs than to find new ones. Managing yourself may involve devoting a portion of your time to speaking with clients or following up with previously completed jobs.
